p: In the light of the DPP-IV inhibitory actions of the 22 plants tested plus the selected phytochemicals, it is notable that flavonoids and their metabolites have been reported to exhibit anti-diabetic activities. An inverse relationship has been suggested also between flavonoid intake and T2DM risk [ 30]. Phytochemicals other than those tested, such as anthocyanin, aspalathin, chrysin, eriodictyol, hispidulin, kaempferol, lepidoside, mangiferin, naringenin, naringin, procyanidin, rhamnoside, terpenoids, vitexin and Lens culinaris extracts have been shown also to exhibit DPP-IV inhibitory activity [ 27, 31]. In addition, a number of other plants (such as A. catechu, M. indica and A. marmelos) have been reported to contain potential phenolic compounds that exert antioxidant effects and DPP-IV inhibitory activity [ 32].
